But it is okay for us to have upwards to 6 patients, out of ratio, and then for them to somehow evaluate us annually when they state they can't even do our job.

review_title: Get in, get the experience and then get out!
job_title: Lift Team Technician in Upland, CA
pros: Good, friendly environment. Good shifts, and opportunities to pick up extra shifts if you are a per diem employee. Cafeteria serves really good food. Health benefits are decent, good opportunity to learn from other staff. Strive to get positions in ICU and CCU, the only departments where staff actually does their job and cares about each other.
cons: Pay is horrible. You don't get paid enough for what you do, and that goes for most hospital staff. You will be overloaded with patients and almost running yourself ragged and management won't even care. Staff plays favorites and most times it's nursing staff against everyone else in a support position. Management is only available when something goes wrong, which is sad. There is no room for advancement or career progression, and if you're looking to transfer departments good luck! You may be the most qualified person for the job but the position will go to someone who knows the manager or director personally. It's all about favoritism at SARH. Safety standards aren't that great. A patient can be in a room for 2-3 days before they realize they should be ISO. It's not safe. Charge nurses are LAZY, especially in the Tele units. You'll find more nurses sleeping than actually doing their job. Like I said, get the experience and move on.

pros: eh eh eh eh eh

pros: Great work environment. Great co workers
cons: None. Great job. Great environment

pros: Pay is decent, shifts go by fast because you’re so busy, co-workers are the best part of this hospital, new tower is clean and kept up.
cons: Pay could be more competitive with other acute care hospitals, management has favorites, lots of family members work here so there is nepotism and can be very cliquey. Huge difference between the new tower and older parts of hospital and the patients know it, not a comfortable work environment in the older areas with 2 patients to a small room, patients are unsatisfied with this inconvenience especially after long hours waiting in ER. More and more job duties without increase in pay or staffing. Disconnect with upper management. Difficult communication with doctors, most round on patients and do not listen to their concerns, are out of the room in less than a minute. Admitting patients to wrong level of care for time and convenience purposes, putting patient safety at risk. Inconsistent rules and communication between departments and management.

pros:
Great team of nurses to work with- you will always have help and support.
New grads in the ER get 6 months of orientation before starting on their own. Great education/ resources available. 
Management is very involved and hands on. 
STEMI center and strike center- so a lot of experience.
Physicians work well alongside staff, overall great team dynamic.
Updated facility in the last 5 years.
cons:
Budget cut issues- a lot of “tightening the belt” in the department, even prior to CV-19. 
Some inconsistencies regarding starting salary for new grad nurses vs nurses with experience— but this is an HR issue, not necessarily anything against the hospital. 
Staffing due to budget cuts— usually at the minimum/ bare bones staffing which truly calls for a team effort to clear the lobby when we see an average of 200+ patients a day

review_title: Good for a first time job
job_title: Food Service Worker in Upland, CA
pros: It can be a good first job for anyone who needs work experience. It also can open many doors from within the transfer programs to move around the hospital. And you definitely gain different knowledge of how to problem solve and manage any situations that arise.
cons: Sometimes the schedule is not very flexible, Sometimes there can be a cap on the hours you receive as full time and part time.

pros: This is a not for profit hospital which has great people and a solid management team. The education benefits are $15,000 over a lifetime, dispersed UpTo $3000 per year. The health insurance coverage costs very good, especially if you use SARH.
cons: Pay is average for the area, but hospital annually reviews for market value and adjusts salaries accordingly.

review_title: Globally positive with room for improvement.
pros: Generally a good place to work. Good benefits with average pay.  There are many staff members that work here for the right reasons, to help mankind.  They make it enjoyable.
cons: A 1900s culture that is extremely resistant to change.  Company slogan should be, "Well, we've always done it that way," or "That won't work here."  No management training for charges or leads.  No longevity incentives.

pros: Good 401k, good benefits, clean hospital, fair work equipment, Free CPR renewal classes, free flu shots, good body mechanic classes, good learning experience.
cons: Way too much work that has nothing to do with patient care, Way too much responsibilities, everybody carries a "Tracker" some type of GPS device, the hourly $ pay is bad, & your yearly "Reviews" are always "meets" Never do you "Exceed" because that means a higher raise. If you're "Older" forget it. My Opinion here Only. Try for yourself!

review_title: Nursing leadership lacks trust in subordinates
job_title: Telemetry/PCU/Post Cardiac Care in Upland, CA
pros: A handful Great recruiting staff are always willing to go the extra mile for your pt's and fellow staff
cons: Middle management quite frankly are all better off set out to be eusthanized.  Many lack The vision and know how to motivate staff to want to make a change for the  betterment of patient outcomes and patient satisfaction and all this can be achieved I'll Beit not as easy as it sounds but staff can only be outstanding when they are at work.  Simple equation to remember Happy Staff will always result IN increased patient satisfaction scores across the board....and patient wise there is no difficult patient just professional staff that can't make a meaningful connection and establish a personalized approach to catering to a patients idiosyncrasies.    Happy peppy staff will alwYs  results in increased patient satisfaction and overall satisfactionacross the board given the proper prep time.

pros: Working at San Antonio Regional Hospital is like working with a wonderful family.    You get to interact and meet so many wonderful employees who all have the same mission and goals....to take compassionate care of patients whether you are an RN, Tech, biller, housekeeper, or any other employee.
cons: No negatives, I enjoyed coming to work!
